Author: Photographer unknown
Title: 5. Second St John's Parochial School and St John's Anglican Church
Notes:
Research notes:

Initial reflection: The models of the cars indicate that the image was perhaps taken a decade before the school was demolished in 1966.

Structured reflection: This aerial image depicts the school (left of the picture), the church, rectory with neighbouring buildings and vehicles. The photograph is taken from Darlinghurst Road facing east. At the back of the school, church and rectory are Victoria St with Surrey St in the background. All the extant buildings in this location are dated from the early 1900s to the 1940s. The presence and models of the motor vehicles enable the image to be dated to the late 1950-early 1960s. The aerial view indicates that the image was likely shot from a helicopter. The photograph appears to be purposely shot, but it would look remarkably different if taken from the back of Victoria St.
File Attachments: /Users/jesmondcalleja/Zotero/storage/JT4YWDXD/Aerial shot of St John's Parochial School and St. John's Anglican Church, Darlinghurst.jpeg
Manual Tags: Darlinghurst; cars; church; historic buildings; rectory; school

Author: Photographer unknown
Title: 6. Rough Edges
Notes:
Research notes:

Initial reflection: Rough Edges' bright, coloured painted walls evoke a place of serenity, compassion, and kindness.

Structured reflection: This image is taken from the northeast on Victoria Street, showing the community drop-in centre Rough Edges. The walls of Rough Edges are colourful and have been painted with striking murals displaying some of Darlinghurst's iconic structures, including the Church. The building is situated at the back of the Church and depicts one of its workers walking toward the camera.
Manual Tags: Darlinghurst; local community; homelessness; mural; drop-in centre

Author: Government Printing Office
Title: 2. First St John's Parochial School and St John's Anglican Church
Notes:
Research notes:

Initial reflection: The school and the church are surrounded by a sterile environment.

Structured reflection: This image shows the school (background) and the church, probably taken not long after the construction of the school was completed and before the spire was added to the church. This produces a date circa 1866 - 1875. The photograph was taken from the northwest on Victoria Street.

Author: Longford, Raymond; Tauchert, Arthur; Lyell, Lottie; Robinson, Stanley
Title: 4. The Sentimental Bloke
Notes:
Research notes:

Initial reflection: This is a still from the 1919 Australian silent movie classic The Sentimental Bloke.

Structured reflection: While the school housed children from poorer families, many students had prominent careers in the arts. A student at the school, Raymond Longford became a world-class movie director with movies such as The Sentimental Bloke adding to his directorial fame. This still is from the original 1919 movie showing Arthur Tauchert and Lottie Lyell. The movie has been recently digitised by the National Film and Sound Archive.
Manual Tags: movie; Raymond Longford; Arthur Trauchert; Lottie Lyell; Australian cinema; still; silent movie; Woolloomooloo

Author: Photographer unknown
Title: 3. Slate writing materials
Notes:
Research notes:

Initial reflection: This image depicts some of the slate-writing materials recovered from the excavation of the school. While all of the artefacts in this image are sherds, photographic scale rulers can be seen in the foreground, indicating the sizes of the objects.

Structured reflection: The appearance of slate-writing materials throughout the archaeological record indicates that they were used in the school for teaching purposes. While production spanned from 1770 to 1900 (Davies 2005), the archaeological evidence suggests that they were still used at this school up until the 1960s. While they are regarded as unhygienic, their constant use throughout the school’s history sheds light on the socio-demographics of the community.

Davies (2005) Writing slates and schooling. Australasian Historical Archaeology, 23, pp.63-69.
Manual Tags: education; school; slate; writing material; clerical; archaeological excavation; Victorian

Author: Galvin, Mike
Title: 7. Darlo Darlings
Notes:
Research notes:

Initial reflection: This is the hero image of the Facebook local community group Darlo Darlings. Depicted in this shot are the number of members, thumbnail images of some of its members and the type of group.

Structured reflection: Darlo Darlings's Facebook page shows a heart with the postcode 2010 etched inside it. The page centres on the local community of Darlinghurst and Surry Hills, both sharing a postcode of 2010. This group provides a supportive and non-judgemental platform where people can discuss and post items relating to the neighbourhood. These posts range from historical articles to current news.
Manual Tags: Darlinghurst; social media; Facebook; local community

Author: Taylor Constructions
Title: 8. HammondCare, Darlinghurst
Notes:
Research notes:

Initial reflection: HammondCare is the focus of this image and is a large 5-storey complex nestled among a leafy environment.

Structured reflection: An street view of HammondCare built on the school site was taken from a nearby building on Darlinghurst Road from the southwest. The image clearly shows the church in the right foreground.

Author: Government Printing Office
Title: 1. St John's Parochial School, Trigonometrical Survey
Notes:
Research notes:

Initial reflection: This map depicts a section of Darlinghurst clearly showing the geographical boundaries of the school and church.

Structured reflection: This is a detailed view of a larger trigonometrical survey map of the city of Sydney, 1855-1865. Included in this larger map are the areas of Darlinghurst, Potts Point and Rushcutters Bay. This map is also of interest as it shows historical names of streets, changes to street formations, and demolished buildings.
File Attachments: /Users/jesmondcalleja/Zotero/storage/AZ6Q99LF/St John's School and Church, Trigonometrical Survey, 1855-1865.jpeg
Manual Tags: Darlinghurst; church; school; map; trigonometrical survey
